request_pathways.name: Advanced Authorization for Release of Information

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient must use a generic dual-purpose ROI authorization form, checking 'Release Information to' and listing themselves as the recipient to request their own records.

red_flags: Zero fillable PDF fields despite August 2025 revision date
Requests last four SSN digits unnecessarily
bright_spots: Explicit HIPAA Right of Access citation (45 CFR § 164.524) telling patients they need not give a reason
Spanish-language version of ROI form available
Text-message alternative channel for ROI requests
Adolescent privacy protections for MyChart proxy access (ages 12-17)

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with a site-scoped search; well-organized forms page with clear section headings and direct PDF links, though generic web searches did not surface ANHC-specific results.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: Digitally composed PDF with text layer but zero fillable fields; a patient could use PDF annotation tools as a workaround and submit via fax (907-743-7255), fitting 'usable digitally with workarounds; fax submission available.'

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized single-page form with clear introductory instructions, logical flow, and granular record-type checkboxes; minor issues include unnecessary SSN collection, a typo, and dense layout from compressing all content onto one page.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the generic authorization form but it wasn't designed for self-access — they must figure out to check 'Release Information to' and list themselves; partially offset by explicit HIPAA Right of Access citation.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: Minor ambiguities — fee language doesn't clarify patient self-access cost limits and SSN collection is unnecessary — but the form includes explicit Right of Access citation, no-conditioning statement, clear revocation rights, and appropriate 42 CFR Part 2 handling.

overall.summary: ANHC's forms are easy to find and include strong patient-rights language and multilingual support, but the generic authorization pathway and non-fillable PDF limit the patient experience.
